Skut,"2016-01-08T05:58:29.893Z","Heights and depths in one set","

Overall this is a
column4: It has lots of play value and some great features, although it does have a few flaws as well.&nbsp

column3: t know how strictly realistic it is to have a helicopter deploying a submersible, but in terms of play value it rocks!&nbsp
column4: Plus your kids will learn fine motor coordination and patience attempting to&nbsp
column5: snag the submarine back onto the chopper&#39

column1: The build is entertaining without being too taxing - the only help a small person may need is fitting the string to the helicopter'
The helicopter model is lots of fun and has great features - a side door, cargo winch and rear ramp.
column2: Its overall appearance is nice and well-proportioned
column6: ve come since the catastrophe that was 4439 heavy lift helicopter only three years before this model.&nbsp
column7: Nevertheless Lego has still chosen to base the&nbsp
column9: this chopper on a Chinook rather than a Sea Knight, which is a shame because the Sea Knight, with rear sponsons and a tricycle undercarriage, is a more authentic &quot
column11: helicopter and is better looking than the Chinook (side sponsons and quad undercarriage).&nbsp
column15: undercarriage which tends to flop around everywhere as the chopper flies around.&nbsp
column16: Heaven knows what happens when you land it on a pitching deck...

column1: To the submarine... The sub is very attractive in terms of colour scheme, but has a weird and frustrating flaw that the windscreen does not cover the opening at the front.
column3: s Lego City, not a scale model, but surely a watertight submarine is not too much to ask?&nbsp
column4: The manipulator arms are also rather stubby - it makes the sub a bit T-Rex like and I can&#39
column5: t really see how this sub could interact with anything on the ocean floor.&nbsp
column6: Frankly, the submarines from the (Town) Divers series in 1997 were superior in terms of looks and play value.&nbsp
column8: t yet built the other subs from the 2015 Deep Sea Explorers line so I can&#39
column9: t comment on whether this is a general problem&nbsp
column10: or if it is unique to this particular sub.&nbsp

column2: City is not renowned for its minifigs but this set is something of an exception
column3: the combination of chopper pilot, diver and submersible pilot give a great variety of colours, functions and accessories.&nbsp
column4: The shark is also a very useful addition, though it was a bit&nbsp
column5: unfair that the set designers didn&#39
column7: a speargun. What with the non-watertight submarine it seems Lego wants Davy Jones to hold onto his treasures (and any Lego minifigs foolish enough to venture underwater with their substandard kit)!

column1: Unfortunately the set contains stickers printed on Lego'
column2: s infamous low quality white paper.&nbsp
column3: This is compounded by the fact that stickers are to be applied to the (curved) sides of the chopper&#39
column5: Good luck getting those ones to stay on!&nbsp
column6: I hear rumours that the 2016 City sets contain a new sticker material
column9: s an improvement on the current version, whose typical lifespan is around 2 years before cracking up and falling off.&nbsp
column10: That sort of low quality might work for other toy brands but Lego should be (and otherwise usually is) built to last.&nbsp

column1: Notwithstanding the small gripes above, the detractions can'
column2: t take away from what is, in the final analysis, a very well conceived and fun set.&nbsp
column3: Kids will really love this set and it should see many hours of happy play.&nbsp

This is the fourth review in my Deep Sea Explorers
This set comes in a medium sized City box. It shows the helicopter winching the submersible out of the water with the submersible
column2: grasping a treasure chest in one of the robotic arms.

column1: A scuba diver is swimming on the surface with a grey reef shark snapping at the missed submersible.

column2: book 1 makes the yellow submersible, book 2 makes the helicopter fuselage&nbsp

column1: There is a medium sized sticker sheet. I tend not to apply stickers to my LEGO and many of these stickers
column2: should be applied onto curved surfaces.

column1: The parts come in three bags that match the three instruction books.
This set introduces a few parts in Earth Blue for first time
column5: and the helicopter cockpit. I really like this earth blue colour.

column1: There are also some new yellow parts in this set

underneath an orange vest. She has a small radio in the vest pocket.

column1: The helicopter pilot is wearing a red and white striped flight jacket with a safety harness. He has blue trousers with flight
column2: suit knee pockets. In the pocket on his left knee he has a weather map and in the right knee pocket there is a marker pen.
print on the rear. The helicopter pilot&#39
column3: s jacket continues the red and white stripes with&nbsp
column6: special watertight zipper, air hoses and more diver&#39
column7: s weights and the Deep Sea Explorers logo is printed on the back of the torso of the submersible pilot.

column1: The two nautical outfits are unique to the Deep Sea Explorers
column2: theme but the helicopter pilot has been seen in LEGO City sets since 2012.

column1: Book 1 with bag 1 first makes the two nautical minifigures, grey reef shark and treasure chest. The build then turns to making the yellow submersible.
The submersible pilot is in the yellow pressure hull. There are two yellow oxygen tanks protected by strong black frames.
There are two small robotic arms and the submersible has plenty of lighting for seeing through murky water.
The clear dome does not completely seal the pressure hull.
Books 2 and 3 together with the corresponding bags makes the helicopter.
The helicopter has a cargo ramp and two side cargo doors that open. There is a winch operated from the left (port) side.
The helicopter has a pair of tandem rotors and looks very similar to Boeing CH-47
All four wheels are on castors so the helicopter
column2: can drive around in any direction it chooses.
have not applied the stickers to this set. I think it still looks great without them.

column1: This helicopter has enormous play features. The winch operates very easily and lifts the submersible well. There could have been some cargo on a pellet stowed in the rear of the helicopter but it would be easy to make something up with 4x2 bricks.

column2: Boeing CH-47 Chinook has a lifting capacity of 12,700&nbsp
column8: (13 short tons), just inside the lifting capacity of this helicopter.

column1: I do hope that LEGO sets like the sets in the Deep Sea Explorers theme helps raise the awareness of scientific exploration in children.
There are small submersibles similar to the one in this set operating at oceanographic research institutes.
